cards.Front: Added sugars: WHO vs AHA limits
cards.Back: WHO: <10% kcal (goal <5%). AHA: ≤100 kcal/day (women/children/teens) or ≤150 kcal/day (men). Examples: 24 g vs 36 g sugar.

cards.Front: Top sources of added sugars in US diets
cards.Back: Sugar‑sweetened beverages; breads/rolls/tortillas; sweet bakery products; coffee/tea drinks; sugars/syrups/jams; fats/oils (dressings/condiments); ready‑to‑eat cereals; other prepared foods.

cards.Front: Saturated fat: AHA limit & high‑SFA foods
cards.Back: Limit to 5–6% of kcal. High sources: fatty cuts of beef, pork, lamb; salami/sausages/processed meats; many fast foods; lard; butter; cheese; coconut & palm oils.
Whole plant foods are usually low in SFA; exceptions include tropical oils (coconut, palm). Nuts/seeds vary (~1–4 g/oz). Avocado ~2.1 g/100 g; most plant oils 1–2 g/Tbsp (except coconut/palm).

cards.Front: Sodium: main contributors & counseling rule of thumb
cards.Back: ~70%+ comes from purchased/restaurant foods. Keep mg sodium per serving ≤ calories per serving to roughly stay ≤2,300 mg/day.
Industrial trans fats removed from US food supply (GRAS revoked). Still occurs naturally in some animal foods; scan labels/ingredients for partially hydrogenated oils.
Calcium*, Fiber*, Potassium*, Vitamin D*, plus Vitamin A, C, E, K, Magnesium, Choline (*=public health concern).
AI ≈14 g per 1,000 kcal (~25 g women, ~38 g men). Sources: legumes, whole‑grains, vegetables, fruits, nuts, seeds (no fiber in animal foods).
5% DV or less = low; 20% DV or more = high, per serving.
Look for “100% whole” and the word ‘whole’ before the grain; avoid ‘multigrain’, ‘made with whole grain’. Use 10:1 carbs:fiber screen for packaged grains.
Low in whole plants; high in red/processed meat, refined grains, added sugars, sodium, UPFs. Linked to obesity, CVD, T2DM; UPFs drive excess kcal and mortality risk.
Lower risk of diabetes, IHD, some cancers; emphasizes legumes, whole grains, fruits/veg, nuts/seeds; limit animal products/refined foods.
Mediterranean + DASH; emphasize greens/berries; reduce meats/sweets/fried foods/cheese; fish ~1×/wk. May protect against Alzheimer’s.
Plant‑predominant patterns associate with lower oxidative stress/inflammation; frying oils generate aldehydes (LOPS).
Nutrient density winners: vegetables (incl. mushrooms), herbs/spices, fruits, legumes, whole grains, nuts, seeds.
Diet high in sodium has the highest attributable mortality globally; low whole grains/fruits/nuts & seeds/vegetables also major contributors.
Higher adherence → ~41% lower CVD mortality & ~27% lower incidence; PREDIMED: Med + EVOO/nuts ↓ major CV events.
Replace with water/unsweetened drinks; aim <10% kcal added sugars (goal <5%); check labels for syrups and ‘-ose’.

cards.Front: Vignette: High LDL‑C on processed ‘keto’ snacks
cards.Back: Shift to whole‑food plant‑predominant; ↑ soluble fiber; nuts/seeds; reassess in ~3 months.
Home‑prep meals 5+ days/week; mg≤kcal rule; request no added salt; consider DASH/Mediterranean.
